reviews.title: Not worth it
reviews.text: I was so excited to take a ride on this toy train, but got totally disappointed after taking it. Earlier I had a ride on toy train in Shimla. I am giving my view point and it is nothing close to the one in Shimla. Even the ticket is on higher side. The views are of no match at all. Total waste of money and time.

reviews.title: HATED THE EXPERIENCE!!!!!!!
reviews.text:
AWFUL!! World Heritage my foot. WAS NOT worth it to spend 9000 rs for 6 people. Reasons:
• Unhygenic - had banana peels
and kulad glasses all over the
floors. And the floor was filled with
dirt.

• Filled with mosquitos and weird
bugs.

• Seats, window locks and handles
broken/torn.

• The train just traveled on the road
and no scenic view was visible.

• The train was delayed by 2 hours.

• Wasted my whole day and was not
able to visit any tourist place apart
of the dirty railway station.

• The only thing the train was best at
is noise and air pollution. ( I went
on a steam train)

• Got a headache from all the
unnecessary horns.

• The train had SPIDERS from like
Australia or smtg.

I do not recommend to visit this overhyped place. Go to Shimla if you want a FAR better experience. Or just atleast remove this as one of the world Heritage places for the sake of the reputation of Indians/India at least.

reviews.title: Recommended when in Darjeeling…
reviews.text: We took the Darjeeling toy train from DHR and back which is a 2 hour journey by diesel or steam engine. We took the diesel version and the coaches were like vista dome providing a 360 degree view. The scenes are beautiful and you get to experience the legendary toy train rode with a visit to Batasia loop and Ghum station.

reviews.title: A unique joy-filled experience
reviews.text:
Initially I was cribbing about the high price of the ticket but at the end of the day, I must admit it was an amazing experience and payment of Rs 1500/- per passenger didn't go waste. Darjeeling Himalayan Railways (DHR) consists of a small ( Narrow Gauge) single line from Darjeeling all the way to New Jalpaiguri but tourists usually
undertake the joy ride (round trip from Darjeeling to Ghum and back). This joy ride is a must do thing while you are in Darjeeling particularly if you have kids in your group. Even for adults it is real fun traversing through the town - at times almost as if piercing THROUGH the buildings on the road - very much reminiscent of Kolkata trams. The round trip of Darjeeling - Ghum - Darjeeling takes around 100 mts. The train stops at Batasia Loop for 20 mts and for 15 mts at Ghum, which happens to be the highest Rail station in India. Batasia Loop is an excellent place for photography offering panoramic views of the Darjeeling city from a height. At Ghum, you can visit the small Rail Museum built at the station itself, have snacks and tea and click photographs. There are some heritage wagons and coaches, selfie points and a heritage Steam Loco where you can get clicked posing as a train driver ! Alternatively, you can visit the Ghum Monastery which is a little way up from the station and you have to walk brisk to cover it within the 15 mts stoppage time. Normally they attach only 2 coaches and the first coach in the UP direction becomes the rear coach in DN after loco reversal at Ghum. Production of Steam engines has been stopped by Indian Railways but at this UNESCO heritage site, you can witness first hand how they actually coal the fire and operate a Steam loco - a unique experience.

reviews.title: Darjeeling, Toy Train - An experience not to be missed!
reviews.text:
If you are visiting Darjeeling, then do not miss to book your tickets on IRCTC from Darjeeling to Darjeeling!
This is close to a 1.5 hour travel with close to 2 stops (20 mins each approx). The train travels through the streets of Darjeeling and it's a must try experience! The ticket costs INR 1000 each approx.

reviews.title: Smoky ride though the crowded streets on a train!
reviews.text:
It's larger than what I'd call a "toy" train although not full size. As you ride up into Darjeeling you can see the tracks criss-crossing the road, cutting across the hairpin bends and in places support on pillars outside the road itself. It's quite an engineering masterpiece getting the track up the hill.
The tourist train tends to be steam driven but you'll see other trains pulled by diesel engines too.
It's not an amazing ride but it's a bit of nostalgia.

reviews.title: Worst toy train experience from Ghoom to Darjeeling
reviews.text:
Worst experience ever !! Not recommended
Booked to board the toy train from Ghum station for a distance of 45min, but it was delayed by 9 hours. We have to board the train @3pm and it arrived at 09:30pm. It was also acceptable if the station master has allowed to board another toy train of same destination; station master denied that as well. People are not helpful but are very soft and sweet voice tone.

reviews.title: Waste of time & money
reviews.text:
Complete waste of time. You pay a fortune to travel across the town and back! Having visited Batasia Loop the day before, I couldn't find one spot along the entire route, worth photographing.
Other than the novelty value of having travelled in a steam engine drawn narrow gauge train, I found nothing to write about....

reviews.title: Toy train ride, Darjeeling.
reviews.text:
Enroute were amazing views, especially of valleys. The road and rail tracks run together and criss cross several times.
Lot of construction done by the rail side is not pleasant to eyes. Wonder how such thing was permitted by concerned authorities.

reviews.title: Don’t waste your time and money
reviews.text:
Sounds a lot better than it is. Very little legroom, skinny seats. Departing very late.

We were on the steam locomotive trip and the locomotive spewed soot/ash onto our car and into our compartment. It was on everything and in my hair. Some of the ash was very hot and singed my skin.

Did I mention that you should wear hearing protection? 103 db whistle blowing all the time.

I suggest looking at the locomotives and calling it good. I had hoped for better photo opportunities but it didn’t happen.
